description.narrative:
European Partnership Foundation (EPF) in Armenia has submitted an application to Sida for support to the project "Civil Society Support for Ensuring Impact on Reforms". The proposed duration of the project is 24 months, and the estimated budget is 1 476 773 USD, which amount to approximately 13 500 000 SEK.
The overarching objective of the proposed project is to "support the civil society in Armenia through building its capacities and strategic positioning to address the needs of the post-revolutionary situation in the areas of Human Rights, Anti-Discrimination and Non-Violence, Anti-Corruption and Conflict of Interest, Environment, Urban Planning and Development".
EPF intends to reach the overall objective by providing support in three main ways: - Support to CSOs responding to the challenges of democratic reform via open door and invited grants. - Capacity building for CSOs. - Networking within the civil society and between the civil society and the government.
The project intend to provide open calls and specific invited grant proposals to altogether approximately 40 CSOs throughout Armenia. EPF will conduct trainings for grant recipients and other CSOs, organize study trips, support networking and platforms for dialogue among civil society organisations and between civil society and the government. The project further aims to ensure that the watchdog and whistle-blower functions of the civil society will not be compromised as a result of increased dialogue and collaboration between the civil society and the government, something which is considered a risk in Armenia as many representatives of the rather newly established parliament and the government, themselves comes from the civil society.

Organisationen EPF har ansökt till Sida om finansiering om totalt 13 500 000 SEK för projeketet "Civil Society Support for Ensuring Impact on Reforms" i Armenien under perioden 2020-2021.
Insatsen syftar till att stödja civilsamhället i Armenien med kapacitetsutveckling och för att strategiskt kunna svara upp till de behov som uppstått efter revolutionen inom områdena mänskliga rättigheter, anti-diskriminering och icke-våld, anti-korruption och intressekonflikt, miljö samt stadsplanering och utveckling.
Insatsens totala budget uppgår till 13,5 miljoner SEK, varav ca 7,3 miljoner SEK kommer att vidareförmedlas till lokala civilsamhällesorganisationer.

The overall objective of the project is to support civil society in Armenia through building its capacities and strategic positioning to successfully address the needs of the post-revolutionary situation in the areas of Human Rights, Anti-Discrimination and Non-Violence, Anti-Corruption and Conflict of Interest, Environment, Urban Planning and Development. The overall objective will be achieved through three sub objectives: 1. CSOs effectively engage in and contribute to the development of the democratic reform agenda (in areas of civic education, public awareness, human rights, grassroots initiatives, government monitoring, etc.) through implementation of open door and invited grant projects. 2. CSOs strengthen their sectoral expertise and knowledge of research methods, monitoring, quality product development, gender mainstreaming, communication and advocacy through the engagement in targeted trainings and the exchange of best practices with foreign counterparts. 3. CSOs benefit from each other’s expertise, build alliances and communicate through a Network, and advocate effectively through government-CSO sectoral dialogue platforms.

description.narrative:
Results of the open-door grants
• National Comprehensive Program on Social Inclusion of People with Disabilities of the 2022-2027 developed by Disability Rights Agenda NGO and adopted by the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs
• Monitoring of health care support from disabled children to all patients conducted and results shared with the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs
• An article on Bird and Biodiversity areas published in the peer reviewed International Journal of Zoology and Animal Biology
• 194 teachers, 209 parents, and 212 students from 20 schools in Shirak region engage in project on excluding bullying at schools
• Mkhitar Sebastatsi educational complex became positioned as a public space for community development via professional workshops for community members. 5 workshops for 75 participants from Mkhitar Sebastatsi Educational Complex and their Malatia-Sebastia community (parents etc.) on addressing community needs, volunteerism
•500 exam questions for the hunters developed, 8 sample exams with 70 questions each
• Engagement of the community members in urban development planning in Dilijan
• Research on economic consequences of COVID-19
• 12,000 cases of people displaced from Azerbaijan in 1988-1992 digitized and stored in electronic databases
• Oral stories about war project also published on Public TV
• Open door grantees reflected their project results in discussion of policy priorities in spheres of education, local self-government, media, urban development with representatives of government.
• Through EPFs targeted capacity building grantee organizations received knowledge on gender mainstreaming, SEAH, anti-corruption and rights based approach in program implementation (this was implemented based on the recommendations from ISK review).
Results of InfoTun invited grants
• Research on the arbitration role of the head of the community in addressing interpersonal issues in the communities of Shirak region
• Comics on expressions of violence in family and school in Vanadzor
• In depth interviews with the healthcare state support recipients on the quality of services in Kotayk
• Research on the cultural life of Martuni community in Soviet period.
• Vayk InfoTun: Trainings on plagiarism in cooperation with Yeghegnadzor University
• A study on oral histories about Soviet repressions in Syunik region
As a result, important local issues identified, grassroots initiatives supported through regional InfoTun projects.
